timeline.event: Related WebKit vulnerabilities CVE-2025-14174 and CVE-2025-43529 patched by Apple in December 2025 updates
Google Threat Analysis Group discovers CVE-2026-20700 in Apple dyld component and reports to Apple
Apple releases iOS 26.3, iPadOS 26.3, macOS Tahoe 26.3, tvOS 26.3, watchOS 26.3, visionOS 26.3 with fix
CISA adds CVE-2026-20700 to Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog with March 5 deadline
Penligent publishes technical PoC analysis showing memory write to code execution chain

simple_summary.what_happened: A critical zero-day vulnerability was discovered in Apple's dyld component, which is the Dynamic Link Editor responsible for loading software libraries on every Apple device. The flaw allows attackers to corrupt memory and execute malicious code. Apple confirmed this was used in extremely sophisticated real-world attacks against specific targeted individuals. Google's Threat Analysis Group found and reported the bug. This is the first actively exploited Apple zero-day of 2026.
simple_summary.who_is_affected: Every Apple device user is potentially affected: iPhones and iPads running iOS/iPadOS before 26.3, Mac computers running macOS Tahoe before 26.3, Sequoia before 15.7.4, or Sonoma before 14.8.4, Apple TVs running tvOS before 26.3, Apple Watches running watchOS before 26.3, and Apple Vision Pro running visionOS before 26.3. Organizations with BYOD policies or Apple device fleets are especially at risk.
simple_summary.what_attackers_do: Step 1: Attackers identify high-value targets such as journalists, activists, government officials, or corporate executives. Step 2: They deliver a malicious payload that exploits WebKit vulnerabilities (CVE-2025-14174 or CVE-2025-43529) to gain initial memory access in the browser or web content process. Step 3: Using the memory write capability, attackers exploit CVE-2026-20700 in dyld to corrupt the dynamic linker's state management. Step 4: The corrupted dyld state allows arbitrary code execution outside the normal application sandbox, gaining deep system access. Step 5: With system-level code execution, attackers install persistent surveillance tools, exfiltrate sensitive data, or maintain long-term access to the compromised device.
what_you_should_do: Immediately update all Apple devices to iOS/iPadOS 26.3, macOS Tahoe 26.3, tvOS 26.3, watchOS 26.3, and visionOS 26.3
For older devices, update to iOS 18.7.5, iPadOS 18.7.5, macOS Sequoia 15.7.4, or macOS Sonoma 14.8.4
Enable automatic updates on all Apple devices to receive future security patches promptly
Review MDM policies to enforce OS version minimums across managed device fleets
Monitor for unusual device behavior including unexpected battery drain, overheating, or unexplained data usage
simple_summary.why_this_is_serious: This vulnerability is particularly dangerous because dyld runs at the core of every Apple operating system, affecting all Apple platforms simultaneously. The exploitation was confirmed as extremely sophisticated and targeted, typically associated with nation-state or commercial spyware operators. Google TAG's involvement in discovery suggests this may be linked to surveillance campaigns. CISA's addition to the KEV catalog with a March 5, 2026 deadline underscores the urgency for federal agencies and all organizations.

tactics.description: Attackers deliver exploit through malicious web content targeting WebKit vulnerabilities to gain initial memory access on victim devices
CVE-2026-20700 in dyld is exploited to achieve arbitrary code execution from memory write capability
The dyld memory corruption allows escalation from sandboxed web content process to system-level code execution
Exploiting the dynamic linker allows bypassing Apple's code signing and sandbox protections
With system-level access, attackers collect sensitive data from the compromised device including messages, photos, and credentials

detection_guidance.summary: Detection of CVE-2026-20700 exploitation is challenging due to its targeted and sophisticated nature. Focus on ensuring all devices are patched, monitoring for anomalous device behavior, and leveraging MDM solutions for compliance enforcement.

log_sources.description: Mobile Device Management solutions can track OS versions and compliance status across device fleets
Monitor for unusual outbound connections from Apple devices, especially to known C2 infrastructure
EDR solutions for macOS can detect unusual dyld behavior, unexpected library loading, or process anomalies

what_to_look_for.indicator: Unpatched Apple devices running iOS < 26.3 or macOS Tahoe < 26.3
what_to_look_for.description: Any unpatched device is vulnerable to this actively exploited zero-day

what_to_look_for.indicator: Unusual dyld loading behavior or unexpected dynamic library injection
what_to_look_for.description: The exploit corrupts dyld state management; anomalous library loading patterns may indicate exploitation

what_to_look_for.indicator: Unexpected outbound network connections from Safari or WebKit processes
what_to_look_for.description: The exploit chain involves WebKit vulnerabilities that may generate abnormal network traffic
what_to_look_for.log_field: process='WebContent' AND dst_ip NOT IN approved_list

immediate_actions.description: Update to iOS/iPadOS 26.3, macOS Tahoe 26.3, tvOS 26.3, watchOS 26.3, visionOS 26.3. For older devices: iOS 18.7.5, macOS Sequoia 15.7.4, macOS Sonoma 14.8.4

immediate_actions.action: Audit Apple device fleet for compliance
immediate_actions.description: Use MDM to identify all devices running vulnerable OS versions and enforce minimum version requirements

immediate_actions.action: Enable automatic updates on all Apple devices
immediate_actions.description: Ensure Settings > General > Software Update > Automatic Updates is enabled on all managed devices

immediate_actions.action: Monitor high-value targets for compromise indicators
immediate_actions.description: Given the targeted nature of attacks, prioritize checking devices used by executives, journalists, and individuals with access to sensitive data
